review.title: Bayesian nonparametric models for ranked data
review.abstract: We develop a Bayesian nonparametric extension of the popular Plackett-Luce choice model that can handle an infinite number of choice items. Our framework is based on the theory of random atomic measures, with the prior specified by a gamma process. We derive a posterior characterization and a simple and effective Gibbs sampler for posterior simulation. We develop a time-varying extension of our model, and apply it to the New York Times lists of weekly bestselling books.

sections.heading: 3 Dynamic Bayesian nonparametric ranking models
sections.text: In this section, we develop an extension of the Bayesian non-parametric Plackett-Luce model to model rankings that vary over time, where the evaluation parameters of items can change smoothly over time and are reflected in a changing ranking order. Given a number of times indexed by t = 1, 2,..., we can model rankings at a time t using a gamma method that distributes the random measurement Gt as in Section 2.2, with the Markov dependence within the scale order (Gt) allowing a dependence between rankings over time.

sections.heading: 3.3 Continuous time formulation using superprocesses
sections.text: The dynamic model described in the previous section is formulated for discrete time data. If the time interval between ranking observations is not constant, it is desirable to work instead with dynamic models that evolve over continuous time, with the underlying random measurements (Gt) defined across all t-R, but with observations at a discrete set of times t1 < t2 < · ·. Here, we propose a continuous time model based on the Dawson Watanabe superprocess [14, 15] (see also [16, 17, 18, 19], which is a diffusion across the measurement space using the gamma process.

sections.heading: 4 Experiments
sections.text: We apply the Plackett-Luce discrete time model to the New York Times bestseller data, which consist of the weekly top 20 bestseller lists from June 2008 to April 2012 in various categories. We look at the categories paperback nonfiction (PN) and hardcover fiction (HF), for which 249 and 916 books appear in the top 20 lists at least once during the 200 weeks, respectively. We consider that the correlation parameter φt = φ is constant over time, and assign flat improper priorities p (α) 1 / α and p (φ) 1 / φ. To take into account the publication date of a book, we do not consider books in the probability prior to their first appearance in a list. We perform the Gibbs pattern with 10,000 burn-in iterations, followed by 10,000 samples.

sections.heading: 5 Discussion
sections.text: Our approach is based on the theory of atomic random measurements, where we have shown that the Plackett-Luce model is exactly the size-related permutation of atoms in random measurement, we have characterized the posterior distribution and derived a simple MCMC sampling algorithm for posterior simulation, our approach can be considered a multi-step generalization of posterior inference in normalized random measurements [21, 22, 23] and can easily be extended from gamma processes to general totally random measurements, we have also proposed dynamic extensions of our model for both discrete and continuous time data, and applied to the modeling of the New York Times bestseller lists. Our dynamic extension can be used by using RR n ° 8140bayesian non-parametric models to model time varying densities or clues in this bestseller model to better collect our observational data.
